text: Right, the cdf wouldn't really come in though right? I mean if it's empirical I'd think you could just go from the data directly

elements.text: Right, the cdf wouldn't really come in though right? I mean if it's empirical I'd think you could just go from the data directly

text: Hmmm good point, but if you think it's a sample from a continuous distribution then you need to estimate either a histogram / KDE or a cdf, eg to calculate the probability of a set that happens to miss all of the data points but is still in the support of the distribution

elements.text: Hmmm good point, but if you think it's a sample from a continuous distribution then you need to estimate either a histogram / KDE or a cdf, eg to calculate the probability of a set that happens to miss all of the data points but is still in the support of the distribution

text: True, but then it's no longer an empirical cdf :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: True, but then it's no longer an empirical cdf

text: I guess a KDE estimate reduces to (1) get the KDE, and (2) build a measure from that. Lots of ways to do (1), so that's probably outside MeasureTheory

elements.text: I guess a KDE estimate reduces to (1) get the KDE, and (2) build a measure from that. Lots of ways to do (1), so that's probably outside MeasureTheory
